title: Koko Hall
text:
Koko is a second-year ScM student at Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, Department of Genetic Epidemiology. She is also a graduate research assistant for the Wendy Klag Center for Autism and Developmental Disabilities.
In her free time, she loves to hike, bake, indoor cycle, go to solidcore, and travel the world!

title: Bio
text:
Koko has research interests in epigenetics and neurodevelopmental disorders. Her current research focuses on evaluating the performance of epigenetic clocks in pediatric populations when measuring the rate of biological aging. She has skills in statistical analysis using R, epidemiologic methods, the implementation of randomized controlled trials, and regulatory work involving the IRB and FDA.


Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health | Baltimore, MD
ScM in Genetic Epidemiology | August 2023-Present
University of Washington | Seattle, WA
B.S. in Psychology (Honors Program) | September 2015 - March 2019

Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health | Graduate Research Assistant | November 2023 - Present
Seattle Children’s Hospital, Department of Neurosurgery | Clinical Research Coordinator III | July 2021-August 2023

title: Example Analysis
text:
Introduction





Caption for Image




Associate Professor of Biomedical Engineering and Biostatistics at Johns Hopkins
Stephanie Hicks is an applied statistician working at the intersection of genomics and biomedical data science.
Her research addresses computational challenges in genomics, epigenomics, and spatial transcriptomics to provide an improved understanding of human health and disease. She develops computational methods using statistical learning and implements these methods in open-source software for biomedical data analysis.
Her research philosophy is problem-forward and solution-oriented, focusing on pressing needs in the field.
